Package algorithms.imageProcessing.matching

Class ORBMatcher

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.imageProcessing.matching.ORBMatcher
  • public class ORBMatcher
extends java.lang.Object
    NOT READY FOR USE. the matchDescriptor methods are not producing reasonable results currently. a class to hold various methods related to matching the descriptors of ORB. See also ObjectMatcher. ORB features can be used to match 2 images as long as the number of points that are possible true matches are larger than the number of points which are not matches in the images. In other words, for the sparse feature matching approach of keypoints, need the number of possible true matches to be larger than the number of possible false matches. If that is not the case, such as in finding an object which has changed location, then the more dense approach of using blob detecter MSER is recommended. NOTE that methods are being added specifically for the sparse matching.
    Author:
    nichole
    See Also:
    ORB

      • matchDescriptors

        public static int[][] matchDescriptors​(algorithms.VeryLongBitString[] d1,
                                       algorithms.VeryLongBitString[] d2,

        greedy matching of d1 to d2 by min cost, with unique mappings for all indexes.
        Parameters:
        d1 -
        d2 -
        Returns:
        matches - two dimensional int array of indexes in d1 and d2 which are matched.

      • matchDescriptors

        public static ORBMatcher.FitAndCorres matchDescriptors​(ORB.Descriptors d1,
                                                       ORB.Descriptors d2,
                                                       double[][] keypoints1,
                                                       double[][] keypoints2)
        greedy matching of d1 to d2 by min difference, with unique mappings for all indexes. NOTE that if 2 descriptors match equally well, either one might get the assignment. Consider using instead, matchDescriptors2 which matches by descriptor and relative spatial location.
        Parameters:
        d1 - descriptors of the keypoints in image 1 (before any keypoint normalization).
        d2 - descriptors of the keypoints in image 2 (before any keypoint normalization).
        keypoints1 - keypoints from image 1 in format [3 X n]. any normalization that is needed should be performed on keypoints1 before given to this method.
        keypoints2 - keypoints from image 2 in format [3 X n]. any normalization that is needed should be performed on keypoints2 before given to this method.
        Returns:
        the matches as pairs of indexes relative to keypoints1 and keypoints2, the epipolar fit fundamental matrix (or essential matrix), correspondence errors and tolerance used in the error analysis. If there were too few points for a fit or if RANSAC failed to find a solution, there will be the unfiltered matched points and null entries in the returned instance of FitAndCorres.

      • matchDescriptors

        public static ORBMatcher.FitAndCorres matchDescriptors​(ORB.Descriptors d1,
                                                       ORB.Descriptors d2,
                                                       double[][] keypoints1,
                                                       double[][] keypoints2,
                                                       boolean useToleranceAsStatFactor,
                                                       double tolerance,
                                                       ErrorType errorType,
                                                       boolean reCalcIterations,
                                                       boolean calibrated)
        greedy matching of d1 to d2 by min difference, with unique mappings for all indexes. NOTE that if 2 descriptors match equally well, either one might get the assignment. Consider using instead, matchDescriptors2 which matches by descriptor and relative spatial location.
        Parameters:
        d1 - descriptors of the keypoints in image 1 (before any keypoint normalization).
        d2 - descriptors of the keypoints in image 2 (before any keypoint normalization).
        keypoints1 - keypoints from image 1 in format [3 X n]. any normalization that is needed should be performed on keypoints1 before given to this method.
        keypoints2 - keypoints from image 2 in format [3 X n]. any normalization that is needed should be * performed on keypoints2 before given to this method.
        errorType - algorithm used to evaluate the fit of the fundamental matrix solutions. * @param useToleranceAsStatFactor if set to false, tolerance is used as * a fixed number in outlier removal, else if set to true, tolerance * is used as the chi-squared statistic factor for the standard deviation * of errors use in outlier removal. * @param tolerance tolerance in distance from epipolar line for a point to * be an inlier in the final fit. NOTE: if useToleranceAsStatFactor is true, * it is interpreted as a chiSqStatFactor which is then used as * tolerance = tolerance * standard deviation of the mean distance errors. * @param reCalcIterations if true, upon each better fit found, the outlier percentage is re-estimated and then the number of iterations necessary for 95% probability that sample has all good points.
        calibrated - if true, solves for the Essential Matrix, else solves for the Fundamental Matrix. The difference is in the diagonal used for dimension reduction.
        Returns:
        the matches as pairs of indexes relative to keypoints1 and keypoints2, the epipolar fit fundamental matrix (or essential matrix), correspondence errors and tolerance used in the error analysis. If there were too few points for a fit or if RANSAC failed to find a solution, there will be the unfiltered matched points and null entries in the returned instance of FitAndCorres.

      • fitWithRANSAC

        public static ORBMatcher.FitAndCorres fitWithRANSAC​(int[][] matches,
                                                    double[][] x1,
                                                    double[][] x2,
                                                    boolean useToleranceAsStatFactor,
                                                    double tolerance,
                                                    ErrorType errorType,
                                                    boolean reCalcIterations,
                                                    boolean calibrated)
        calculate the fundamental matrix given the correspondence matches. the fundamental matrix is calculated, then the errors are estimated using the Sampson's distance as errors and a 3.8*sigma as inlier threshold.
        Parameters:
        matches -
        x1 - (a.k.a. left) data in dimension [3 X n]. any normalization needed should be performed on points before given to this method
        x2 - (a.k.a. right) data in dimension [3 X n]. any normalization needed should be performed on points before given to this method
        errorType - algorithm used to evaluate the fit of the fundamental matrix solutions. * @param useToleranceAsStatFactor if set to false, tolerance is used as * a fixed number in outlier removal, else if set to true, tolerance * is used as the chi-squared statistic factor for the standard deviation * of errors use in outlier removal. * @param tolerance tolerance in distance from epipolar line for a point to * be an inlier in the final fit. NOTE: if useToleranceAsStatFactor is true, * it is interpreted as a chiSqStatFactor which is then used as * tolerance = tolerance * standard deviation of the mean distance errors. * @param reCalcIterations if true, upon each better fit found, the * outlier percentage is re-estimated and then the number of iterations necessary for 95% * probability that sample has all good points.
        calibrated - if true, solves for the Essential Matrix, else solves for the Fundamental Matrix. The difference is in the diagonal used for dimension reduction.
        Returns:
        the matches as pairs of indexes relative to keypoints1 and keypoints2, the epipolar fit fundamental matrix (or essential matrix), correspondence errors and tolerance used in the error analysis. If there were too few points for a fit or if RANSAC failed to find a solution, there will be the unfiltered matched points and null entries in the returned instance of FitAndCorres.
